questions.question_text_1: In Verilog, you need to add two signed fixed-point numbers in 2's complement representation with different bit widths. To ensure the addition produces the correct result, what must you do to the smaller-width operand before adding?
question_texts: In Verilog, you need to add two signed fixed-point numbers in 2's complement representation with different bit widths. To ensure the addition produces the correct result, what must you do to the smaller-width operand before adding?

options.option_text: Pad the smaller operand with zeros on the left to match the larger width
Extend the smaller operand’s most significant bit to match the larger width
Reduce the larger operand’s width by truncating its most significant bits
Directly add the operands without any width adjustments; Verilog handles itautomatically

questions.question_text_1: Consider the following snippet of Verilog code.// 2:1 MUX module mux2( input sel, input [7:0] a, input [7:0] b, output [7:0] out ); assign out = sel?b:a; endmodule //Top Module 4:1 MUX module top_module ( input [1:0] sel, input [7:0] a, b, c, d, output [7:0] out  ); wire W1, W2;  mux2 mux_0 ( .sel(sel[0]), .a(a), .b(b), .out(W1) ); mux2 mux_1 ( .sel(sel[0]), .a(c), .b(d), .out(W2) ); mux2 mux_2 ( .sel(sel[1]), .a(W1), .b(W2), .out(out) ); endmodule What warning or issues are most likely to see when simulating /synthesizing this Verilog code?
question_texts: Consider the following snippet of Verilog code.// 2:1 MUX module mux2( input sel, input [7:0] a, input [7:0] b, output [7:0] out ); assign out = sel?b:a; endmodule //Top Module 4:1 MUX module top_module ( input [1:0] sel, input [7:0] a, b, c, d, output [7:0] out  ); wire W1, W2;  mux2 mux_0 ( .sel(sel[0]), .a(a), .b(b), .out(W1) ); mux2 mux_1 ( .sel(sel[0]), .a(c), .b(d), .out(W2) ); mux2 mux_2 ( .sel(sel[1]), .a(W1), .b(W2), .out(out) ); endmodule What warning or issues are most likely to see when simulating /synthesizing this Verilog code?

options.option_text: Bit-width mismatch on W1 and W2 assignments
Latch inferred in mux2 due to incomplete assignment
Multiple driver on W1 and W2.

questions.question_text_1: In the following Verilog testbench snippet used for simulating a counter design, the clk signal is generated to trigger on the positive edge. Based on the code, select the correct frequency and delay characteristics of the clock signal. Which of the following statements is/are correct?// Clock generation block from testbench initial begin clk = 0; end always #5 clk = ~clk; // 5ns delay
question_texts: In the following Verilog testbench snippet used for simulating a counter design, the clk signal is generated to trigger on the positive edge. Based on the code, select the correct frequency and delay characteristics of the clock signal. Which of the following statements is/are correct?// Clock generation block from testbench initial begin clk = 0; end always #5 clk = ~clk; // 5ns delay

options.option_text: 100 MHz clock with posedge at 5 ns
200 MHz clock with posedge at 5 ns
100 MHz clock with negedge at 5 ns
200 MHz clock with negedge at 5 ns

questions.question_text_1: Consider the following Verilog module and its instantiation. Based on the implementation details, identify which of the following unsigned decimal input combinations for a and b might result in unexpected behavior due to value limitations.// Adder module instantiation  adder #(8) uut (.a(a), .b(b), .sum(sum)); //design code module adder #(parameter WIDTH = 4)( input wire [WIDTH-1:0] a, input wire [WIDTH-1:0] b, output wire [WIDTH:0] sum  ); assign sum = a + b; endmodule
question_texts: Consider the following Verilog module and its instantiation. Based on the implementation details, identify which of the following unsigned decimal input combinations for a and b might result in unexpected behavior due to value limitations.// Adder module instantiation  adder #(8) uut (.a(a), .b(b), .sum(sum)); //design code module adder #(parameter WIDTH = 4)( input wire [WIDTH-1:0] a, input wire [WIDTH-1:0] b, output wire [WIDTH:0] sum  ); assign sum = a + b; endmodule

questions.question_text_1: In a flip-flop, "hold time" refers to:
question_texts: In a flip-flop, "hold time" refers to:

options.option_text: The time required for a signal to transition from high to low.
The minimum time before the clock edge that data must remain stable toavoid metastability.
The time taken for a signal to propagate from input to output.
The minimum time after the clock edge that data must remain stable to avoidmetastability.

questions.question_text_1: Consider the following SystemVerilog module for a 4-bit comparator:module comparator_4bit ( input logic signed [3:0] A, // 4 bit signed binary value A input logic signed [3:0] B, // 4 bit signed binary value B output logic A_gt_B, // When A is greater than B output logic A_eq_B, // When A is equal to B output logic A_lt_B // When A is lesser than B );  always_comb begin if (A > B) begin A_gt_B = 1; A_eq_B = 0; A_lt_B = 0; end else if (A == B) begin // CODE A end else begin A_gt_B = 0; A_eq_B = 0; A_lt_B = 1; end end endmodule  Based on the above data, answer the given subquestions.
question_texts: Consider the following SystemVerilog module for a 4-bit comparator:module comparator_4bit ( input logic signed [3:0] A, // 4 bit signed binary value A input logic signed [3:0] B, // 4 bit signed binary value B output logic A_gt_B, // When A is greater than B output logic A_eq_B, // When A is equal to B output logic A_lt_B // When A is lesser than B );  always_comb begin if (A > B) begin A_gt_B = 1; A_eq_B = 0; A_lt_B = 0; end else if (A == B) begin // CODE A end else begin A_gt_B = 0; A_eq_B = 0; A_lt_B = 1; end end endmodule  Based on the above data, answer the given subquestions.

questions.question_text_1: What is the purpose of the always_comb block in this module?
question_texts: What is the purpose of the always_comb block in this module?

options.option_text: It activates only on the rising edge of a clock signal.
It is used to describe sequential logic using procedural assignments.
It automatically updates outputs whenever any input signal changes.
It enables the declaration and initialization of memory elements.
